artifacts.name: WIPLimit
artifacts.relatedItems: Lead Time in WIP, Throughput, WIP Limit

impactedBy.name: BugRatio
impactedBy.howItRelates: When the Bug Ratio is very high or increasing week by week (result is worsening), it can cause the team to work on more items simultaneously (new demands and bug fixes). This can cause the team to exceed the WIP Limit.

impactedBy.name: LeadTimeByColumn
impactedBy.howItRelates: If there are columns with very high Lead Time (representing 25% or more of the total Lead Time in WIP), it indicates that some stages of the flow are bottlenecked. When we have very large bottlenecks in one stage, or many bottlenecks in several stages (board columns), items tend to stay stuck in a certain phase of the flow for a long time. As a result, the team ends up working on several items in parallel, which exceeds the WIP limit.

impactedBy.name: BlockedTime
impactedBy.howItRelates: Blocked items remain in the same board column until the impediment is resolved. This behavior can cause the WIP Limit to be exceeded.

impactedBy.name: PostStartSprintInclusions
impactedBy.howItRelates: If the team works with scrum and starts adding many new items after the sprint has already started, it may be necessary to parallelize the work more to try to deliver everything by the end of the sprint. This can cause the team to exceed the WIP Limit.

impactedBy.name: LeadTimeInWaitingColumns
impactedBy.howItRelates: When the Lead Time in waiting columns of the board is very high, it may indicate that the team has bottlenecks in the process, such as high wait times for item approval, high wait times for code review, or waiting for items to be published in production. This can leave many items stuck in the flow, increasing the WIP and exceeding the recommended limit.

impactedBy.name: WorkItemWithClearDescription
impactedBy.howItRelates: Poorly described items can create doubts in the team, causing the item to remain in waiting columns, either waiting to be developed, tested, or approved - because people are unsure of what was really expected with the delivery of that item. As a result, the item remains stuck until the doubts are resolved, increasing the WIP.

impactedBy.name: WIPLimit

artifacts.whyIsImportant: When the team exceeds the WIP limit, working on many items simultaneously, deliveries tend to take longer and have lower quality.

artifacts.name: LeadTimeInWaitingColumns
artifacts.relatedItems: WIP Limit, Throughput, Lead Time, Lead Time By Column

impactedBy.name: BugRatio
impactedBy.howItRelates: When the bug ratio is very high or increasing week by week (result worsening), the team's focus may be on fixing these errors, leaving new items stuck in waiting columns.

impactedBy.name: LeadTimeByColumn
impactedBy.howItRelates: If the lead time of the waiting columns is very high compared to the total lead time in WIP, it may indicate that the team has bottlenecks in these phases. We can look at the waiting columns with the highest lead time spent and know where to focus to reduce the lead time spent in waiting columns.

impactedBy.name: WIPLimit
impactedBy.howItRelates: When the team does not respect the WIP limit, they end up working on many things in parallel. When this happens, it is normal for the team to focus too much on working on action columns, taking more items to develop instead of finishing what is already in progress and closer to the end of the board. This leads to abandonment of items in waiting columns, increasing the lead time of these phases.

impactedBy.name: WorkItemWithClearDescription
impactedBy.howItRelates: Poorly described items can create doubts in the team, causing the item to remain stuck in waiting columns, either waiting to be developed, tested, or approved - because people are unsure of what was really expected with the delivery of that item. As a result, the item remains stuck until the doubts are resolved, increasing the lead time of these columns.

impactedBy.name: BugRatio
impactedBy.howItRelates: Many bugs in WIP make the team focus on these corrections and pay less attention to new items. As a result, new items remain stuck in waiting columns, increasing the lead time of these phases.

impactedBy.name: PullRequestWithSizeGreaterThanLimit
impactedBy.howItRelates: Very large pull requests can be difficult to validate, causing some developers to avoid doing code reviews on these items. If the team has a waiting column to map this phase of the process, there may be delays in it, increasing the lead time of the waiting columns.

impactedBy.name: LeadTimeInWaitingColumns
impactedBy.howItRelates: This artifact can be impacted by itself when it occurred in the previous week, indicating that the team is not able to reduce the lead time in waiting columns. The team needs to be informed that this is a recurring problem.

artifacts.whyIsImportant: When the time spent in waiting columns is very high, it means that the team has an inefficiency in the flow and that the items are aging a lot on the board. Besides affecting the delivery capacity, this can make bug fixing more difficult, as the responsible developer may have changed context several times until a bug is reported for the item they developed.

results.title: Waiting time within the limit

results.howIsIdentified: We calculate the total lead time and the lead time of the waiting columns. Then we compare the two, if the total time spent in waiting columns of the flow is less than or equal to 30%, the notification is sent.

results.title: Excessive waiting time
results.description: {0} of the lead time was spent in waiting stages, you are minimizing efficiency and causing unnecessary delays in the process.
results.howIsIdentified: We calculate the total lead time and the lead time of the waiting columns. Then we compare the two, if the total time spent in waiting columns of the flow is greater than 30%, the notification is sent.

artifacts.name: SprintSpillover

impactedBy.name: BugRatio
impactedBy.howItRelates: A high bug ratio during a sprint can prevent the team from completing all planned items, as they had to deal with many unforeseen issues. This can leave some items unfinished, which will need to be carried over to the next sprint.

impactedBy.name: WIPLimit
impactedBy.howItRelates: When the team does not respect the WIP limit, many bottlenecks can occur in the process, preventing the team from completing all planned items for the sprint. As a result, some items may be carried over to the next sprint.

impactedBy.name: BugRatio
impactedBy.howItRelates: A high bug ratio during a sprint can prevent the team from completing all planned items, as they had to deal with many unforeseen issues. This can leave some items unfinished, which will need to be carried over to the next sprint.

impactedBy.name: BlockedTime
impactedBy.howItRelates: Items blocked for a long time (while no one resolves the related impediment) can be delayed, taking more time than estimated. This prevents the team from completing all planned items for the sprint and may require some items to be carried over to the next sprint.

impactedBy.name: HighWorkloadPerPerson

artifacts.name: HighLeadTimeInWipDeviation

impactedBy.name: BugRatio
impactedBy.howItRelates: When the bug ratio is very high or increasing week by week (result worsening), there can be significant changes in Lead Time. Either because small bugs are fixed very quickly and greatly lower the lead time, or because the team pauses current demands to prioritize bug fixes and the Lead Time increases significantly. This behavior repeated over time can generate significant variations in the current Lead Time compared to the team's historical average.

impactedBy.name: WithoutWaitingColumns
impactedBy.howItRelates: When the team's board does not have waiting columns, it is difficult to identify bottlenecks related to poorly defined process stages. For example: approval, code review, production deployment. As a result, the team can have significant variations in Lead Time in WIP and not be able to identify the source of the problem - since the action and waiting stages are not separated.

impactedBy.name: WorkItemSkippingWIPColumns
impactedBy.howItRelates: If it is identified that the team is skipping WIP columns, i.e., moving cards on the board directly from TO DO to DONE without going through the WIP phases. This behavior can generate significant variations in Lead Time in WIP, as the team is not respecting the defined workflow.

impactedBy.name: BlockedTime
impactedBy.howItRelates: When there are work items that remain blocked for a long time, the team can have significant variations in Lead Time in WIP. This happens because the time the item is blocked is not counted in Lead Time in WIP, and when the impediment is resolved, the item is completed very quickly, lowering the Lead Time in WIP.

impactedBy.name: HighLeadTimeInWipDeviation
impactedBy.howItRelates: When it occurs repeatedly week by week, the team needs to be informed that it is a recurring problem. This can indicate that the team is not able to keep Lead Time in WIP stable, which can generate predictability issues.

artifacts.whyIsImportant: A high standard deviation in lead time indicates great variation in delivery times, suggesting inconsistency in the process. Identifying and reducing this variation is crucial to improving predictability and efficiency.

results.title: High lead time variation
results.description: The lead time variation is high, with a standard deviation of {0} hours. This indicates significant inconsistencies in delivery times, which can affect process efficiency and predictability.
results.howIsIdentified: We calculate the standard deviation of lead times. If the standard deviation is greater than 50 hours, we notify that the variation is high and requires attention.

impactedBy.name: HighWorkloadPerPerson
impactedBy.howItRelates: When there are overloaded team members, Pull Requests may become large because the developer does not have time to break the work into smaller parts and ends up doing more things in the PR. As a result, the team may have very large Pull Requests.

impactedBy.name: PullRequestWithSizeGreaterThanLimit
impactedBy.howItRelates: When it occurs repeatedly week by week, the team needs to be informed that it is a recurring problem. This may indicate that the team is not able to keep Pull Requests within the change limit, which can cause code review problems and technical debt.

artifacts.whyIsImportant: Very large Pull Requests can make code review difficult, increasing the likelihood of errors going unnoticed. Monitoring the size of PRs helps to maintain effective and agile code reviews, ensuring code quality.

results.title: Pull Requests within change limit
